O_-DneqzTxGnPbRrFxuVNA.text: Cool location and a modern & a bit upscale menu without being pretentious. Our service was good and everyone in our party enjoyed their meals.

IBAevVl7J6p5KXbGCIx9vw.text: Hm. Not sure why this place isn't getting the recognition that it deserves.But, to each their own, I guess.Anyway, it's been over a year since i last ate here, so I'm a little foggy at what I ate. However, I do remember that it was all sooooooo good and I walked away thinking this joint easily made my top 10 favorite restaurants. I recall that upon approach at the Borough Market, the restaurant looked quite, quite out of place among the hustle, chaos and bustle of the surrounding neighborhood. However, upon entrance into the restaurant, I was pleased at how elegant and wonderful the staff and decor was. On arrival, we asked about wine suggestions and were promptly led to some California selections. Of course, since we LIVE in California, we asked for something European instead, settling on a lovely Italian something-something. D'oh.Anyway, I only recall sampling the pork belly roast which was divine - crispy on the outside with tender (and very well seasoned) meat on the inside. Can't remember what side dishes came with it, but I seem to recall greens, for some reason. Dessert was some sort of apple crumble with vanilla pudding, which actually turned out quite wonderful (but unfortunately, I was too full to actually enjoy it).All in all, this place rocks! If I ever make it back to London someday, I'm making a beeline for ROAST.

KjeIVFAr0PhT0Um56VOoFA.text: Though I had never even noticed this restaurant before on my various trips to the Borough Market, my mother was drawn like a fly to its white tablecloths and well-suited waiters. Thus, after browsing the stalls down below, we made a quick check of the menu and headed upstairs to Roast for a light lunch. I wanted to like it; the menu looked delicious and but unfortunately, they didn't seem to have anything on the menu. I ordered a salad with chicken, walnuts, and stilton. Mum ordered tomato and cheese. Sorry, miss, we're out of that salad.Alright then tomato and shallot.What about dessert? The crumble at the next table looked wonderful. I'll just have a scoop of ice cream. How about the caramel?We don't have that.But...it's on your menu.We don't have it.Ok then, the rhubarb.Alright.(Five minutes later)Sorry miss, we don't have rhubarb.Let's try the cheddar torte.Sorry miss, we're out.Elderflower ice cream then.Alright. (Ten minutes later)Here's your gooseberry ice cream.I realized later there were no walnuts on my salad. Out?

mW84_bUWxO8GCUYUyWm8aw.text: It's beautiful inside, with a very corporate lunch crowd. The food and service are far less impressive. They have a 3-course menu for £30; the (asparagus) soup was served lukewarm at best, though had good flavor. The main was a grilled cod which was completely undercooked; sent it back and got a new one. Then, the dessert we chose was actually unavailable, yet it took a full 10 minutes for them to discover and inform us? By then we had to get back to work so we left without dessert. Servers seemed flustered and agitated with each other, there was apparent disorganization and lots of people waiting for their food.

19tmVKYNy4BkdSXa1xBZXg.text: The space here is immaculate--high ceilings, large windows, and plenty of breathing room to take you away from the hustle and bustle of Bourough Market below.   (I was told the large window wall was actually part of the original Camden Market train depot structure.)The food is incredible.  All the ingredients are fresh from the market and are traditional English favorites.  The two standout dishes were the pigs in blankets (gourmet sausage encased in pastry and served with an amazing horseradish, ketchup and mustard dip) and the carrot cake... which was fabulously done and had an amazing little crispness in the crust that you can't miss.  If you're visiting London, this is a great place to splurge!

NkKd0_crUVvMEn_se8_qzw.text: Have visited Roast twice now, once for breakfast and once for lunch. No booking for breakfast so we were lucky to get a table as it was heaving on Saturday morning. We took the risk and were lucky. Generally, I was underwhelmed by the menu and the food. It was standard breakfast food with nothing really exciting outside of the norm. We both ordered dishes with poached eggs. Both came out hard rather than with a runny yolk. Had to send them back. However, lunch was a different society and I think this is where I would recommend it. I went for the fish and chips which I think is a Friday lunch regular. Wow. The mushy peas were the best I have ever had. Both meals were not cheap, but their quality high. Oh, lastly, coffee was terrible, but we are both coffee snobs. Overall, go, enjoy breakfast but expect nothing out of the ordinary. Lunch, I think this is great mid-week if you are in the area or having a Friday off and tour the markets in the morning before a long lunch at Roast.

photos.caption: Photo of Roast - London, United Kingdom
Photo of Roast - London, United Kingdom. Some of the best fish and chips I have ever had - mushy peas were the highlight

tVf1eCvpuRNV1LMjC92t1g.text: I had a great experience at Roast. The waiter was very knowledgable (if a bit sarcastic, and reluctant to take our wine order!), and the coat staff were very quick and helpful too. I had a corned beef and pickled onion hash to start, which was absolutely lovely, followed by a large and beautifully cooked steak (I couldn't finish it, but I really, really, really wanted to). I had a Chocolate Banoffee Pudding as dessert - heaven in a pot. It's pricey but worth it. Lovely food, nice surroundings, and quick service. I would wholeheartedly recommend it - perhaps more so if someone else is paying!

yrBDhOe_-6HRwIuL-6IZiA.text: Located in the heart of Borough Market, Roast is perfect if you are looking for a restaurant that extra bit special. Most of the food is purchased from the stalls below which I think adds a nice community touch.However the place is always brimming with smart city suit types who can sometimes become quite distracting as the tables are positioned relatively close together. The quality of the food is flawless though and even my fruit salad breakfast was pretty special. With a variety of decadent British dishes including pan fried Cornish skate and Roast rump of beef, the prices (around £20 for a main) definitely reflect the quality.I would recommend going on a weekend as you then tend to avoid the hustle and bustle of the local workers. You are guaranteed a wonderful meal but be prepared to pay!

photos.caption: Photo of Roast - London, United Kingdom

-H922YgimU7H76mpCs7_gA.text: This place has great views. If you're lucky you may nab a table with views out across the passing trains and shimmering floodlit river Thames. Roast's location, on the first floor of Borough Market near London Bridge, is also supposed to reflect its menu choice of quality, fresh, British produce.As the name suggests, there is a focus on roasting as a culinary method. But this vague focus is stretched to fit a wide variety of meat, and fewer vegetable dishes. I tried the rack of Welsh lamb, and tasted the venison, which were both excellent. There were many more dishes on the menu I wanted to try.Prices are high, and the quality of the cooking reflects this, but the service wasn't too smart, unfortunately. The clientele on the night I visited seemed to be made up of either romancing couples, in the window seats, or large, raucous parties of office workers in the longer central tables.

photos.caption: Photo of Roast - London, United Kingdom
Photo of Roast - London, United Kingdom
Photo of Roast - London, United Kingdom

5_7VzYt942R63T2BrqBE-Q.text: The big Daddy of all London breakies award has to go to Roast. It's an absolute Borough hotspot, along with many other fine food establishments in an area that's already top on every foodies eating list.If you're a big meat eater then this is the place to go. I haven't found better meat fry-ups anywhere else, theirs is truly the full monty. I usually go for the 'Smoked streaky bacon and fried egg sanwich' that is roughly an entire pack of bacon in doorstop thick white bread with crusts that could fell a few teeth, dolloped with an egg and lashings of brown sauce. It was actually one of these that led me to abandon my vegetarianism (hey if you're gonna fall off the wagon then do it properly!) But saintly Vegetarians need not worry as there are also some great options like the healthier fruit salad or the muesli with Earl Grey prunes.It is a more up market affair in here, with a stylish yet still comfortable interior and a foodie crowd so I wouldn't recommend piling in after a heavy night out looking rather green. Pop in on a Saturday for the best breakfast south of the River and watch the market below. Breakie finishes at 11am on weekdays and 11.30 Saturdays, so don't lie in too long.

Wmntrsp10t81HpWoWZCHKg.text: My $0.02 I'd heard a lot of good things about Roast and it was always one of those places I wanted to try out, so yesterday I took one of my mates for dinner. The place has a great atmosphere and a relaxed vibe about it but frankly I have to say that I expected more. Service - the coat staff were quite incompetent, with three of them leaving me waiting (and I was the only one there!) for over three minutes. It might not sound like a long time, but it is when you're being ignored and in a restaurant! - I don't think I've ever had a less enthusiastic waiter. No smile, no hello, no goodbye. When questioned "what's the special?", the reply was a one word "mussels". No price, no description, just one word. Food - the food was good, but not £20 a dish good. It was gastropub, £12 - 15 good. For the premium you pay I'd expect better. The belly pork was tasty but in parts very dry. The pheasant portion was rather small. All in all, I'd probably go again on a special offer / TopTable, but not full price. There are plenty of cheaper and better places.

sGCnkUltPUYBIPMCd2RcMw.text: Fantastic meal, would highly recommend the Aubrey Filet.  One of the best dinners I've ever had!

oB6-RDq3P3beRstRc5zVeQ.text: I was at Roast with 10 friends on Sunday 16.11.11 from 12 to 2.30.The food was good and the service very good and we all thoroughly enjoyed our meal until it became the time to pay.The bill had 2 bottles of wine on it, though only one was received at the table so we brought this to the waiters attention, they were not too pleased but relinquished and we paid our bill of £500 odd.We were rudely kicked off of our table as they supposedly had some diners waiting for it though they were not to be seen and we had finished up as quickly as possible but their sorting the bill had delayed us for 10 minutes.  We were then informed that there would be an extra charge of £10 per head for the 8 that didn't appear, we had booked a table for up to 20 but this had been resolved before arrival and we had a table for 12.  This was disputed by us and we left.Once down the road I then realised that the bottle of wine that I had paid for had been over charged up from £24 to £28 plus 12.5% service charge on top.Good food and service ruined by crap attitude of the management - I was and still am 2 days later pissed off.NOT WORTH THE EFFORT

aWCYrIe2BVi5qyLZxArDDw.text: Great location in the market.  Good wine list at reasonable cost for 250ml.  Food was good, not great, but the worst part is that it is very expensive for what you get.  Service was also very mediocre.

a-BvllzPpcb1uXLjSsWTIw.text: Staying at a nearby hotel, it seemed easy to pop in to this place for dinner. Being alone, I wanted to eat at the bar.  The host gave me HUGE attitude and judgement about dining alone, and tried to seat me at a small table in a sequestered/forgotten corner of the restaurant where it would be easy to "forget" about me. He was SUCH a jerk, I decided to go elsewhere, where I had a wonderful dinner, AT THE BAR, and a nice conversation with other patrons, to boot. Bottom line, it doesn't matter if your food is good if the service at the front desk SUCKS so badly that your potential customers leave.

5RMiIysFyBDFASWf7c3WDw.text: I'm not sure why Roast has such mediocre reviews. I came here for the Sunday Roast and thought it was great.I had their potted shrimps and the roast sirloin of Welsh black beef. The shrimp was delicious (and a generous helping), and the prime rib was perfectly cooked. My boyfriend had the scallops as an appetizer, and they were tender and delicious. I was not a big fan of either of the side dishes (potatoes and brussel sprouts), but I was too full from the other food to care. So delicious!

K-WzhngAmf3xoT4uuT20UA.text: Took me ages to find the place - if you have not been before it's worth doing your homework rather than relying on electronic devices on the way! Great British traditional food - some of dishes you have to order before you go, again worth checking into if its your first time.Not a casual attire place and you will share the restaurant with suits in the evening. Expensive but worth a visit.

Toe-p9CFZjmmicrUkPsNVQ.text: Roast is in a converted industrial space overlooking borough market with an old world ambience however service and food is lackluster at best. Took a group there recently on their set full and veggie brunch menu. The food came promptly but service was non existent.  When the bill came, the waiter added a service charge and an extra 90GBP surcharge for a few people who weren't able to join. Surprising since the restaurant was near empty, they had been advised of lower numbers and considering our group had patronized the restaurant quite a number of times before. The food itself  (British fare) is dull - left a lot more to be desired. If you want good English food in the area, try Garrison or even Fish with similar ambience. Avoid Roast

knruOC3GfMZMtEb0sOHMJw.text: As other reviewers have stated, Roast does exactly what it says on the tin, but at a price. Roasts and other classic English dishes, well made with quality ingredients which wouldn't be out of place in the stalls of the Borough Market below. My dining companion and I went for the three course £26 "Market menu", which during our visit offered a selection of starters (such as tomato soup or potted salt beef), mains of duck, trout, pork and a vegetable tart, and a desert selction including potted fig and an apple pie with custard. Everything we sampled was well presented and fantastic tasting. The restaurant itself was quite full (although it was a Saturday night), but we were lucky enough to be given a window table, providing views overlooking the borough market and the other restaurants below. My only criticism of Roast would be the expensive wine list, a minimum of £20 for a 500ml caraffe of wine, moving up to £30 minimum for a bottle is pricey. Nevertheless, the South African 2008 Quando Sauvignon Blanc was very nice, and not a wine you usually see on menus. With a meal for 2 with wine coming to £100, it's not your typical pub roast, but recommended if you want to treat yourself.

zm8f___HiIb7KJgyWJY9BQ.text: Roast perplexes me. I absolutely loved my dish- pork roast special but absolutely hated my husband's- fillet mignon. My pork was so delicious that I am still thinking about it and looking for a reason to return very soon. It was so moist, so flavorful, and the skin had the greatest light and crispy crunch. My husband's steak on the other hand tasted like it was precooked and rewarmed for serving. Lo and behold, we saw a giant tray of precooked fillet mignons in the kitchen window when we left. Unlike me, he is not in a hurry to go back to Roast. The rest of the dishes were just average. I guess the moral of the story is to eat roasted food at Roast.

rsuECVSI9e9y39luPzlInQ.text: We went back to Roast to try the dinner menu.  There was some confusion with the price: we had booked on OpenTable and thought we would be getting the set menu for a good price, however it turned out that this was only applicable at certain times.  This was disappointing at the time because we felt some pressure to continue with a dinner more expensive than we were expecting.But from our last experience here for a Sunday roast, we knew that the food would be good, so we stuck with it.  We got a huge t-bone steak for us both to share with some onion rings.  We asked for medium, but it came out quite rare.  We sent it back to be cooked a bit more and it came back just as we liked it.  It was delicious.  I like the idea of sharing a big steak and I will do this more often.Having been there a couple of times now, I agree that it is on the expensive side and is something of a treat.  We will be more careful about checking the details of website "deals".

m8Kx0pQxfRtieJCneRcVcw.text: Good food, tightly packed dining room, seriously overpriced wine. I have been to Roast a few times over the past couple of years and I came to the conclusion that I probably won't be returning. It's extremely expensive, but I usually don't mind paying for quality. I just get the feeling that I am being 'had' on a few things! The dining room is very tightly packed, especially on the tables for two down the sides of the mezzanine floor. My friend and I went there last week and were literally sitting on the same table as an extremely amorous couple next to us. It just wasn't pleasant for either party! The food is good - I have never had anything that wasn't jolly nice there. I have tried the goat curry, the various daily specials, fish, chicken, steak... and all have been really nice. What really annoys me about this place is the wine list. I know wine, and I know that 50 quid for a bottle of Marlborough Sauvignon Blanc (not even Cloudy Bay) is pushing it rather a lot. Also, the service could be better. I have never had the rude experience that other reviewers have had, but you are somehow made to feel that you are an imposition and there's not a great deal of warmth or attention in the delivery. So, I have come to the stunning realisation that there are plenty of very good restaurants in London that will feed me decent food, let me sit down without having to introduce myself to my fellow diners and will serve me a wine with a generous mark up, but that doesn't leave me feeling fleeced.

K8YrVQX0FlKEQ3Y4w-QVyg.text: Came here for a large work outing at Christmas. Food was good but expensive for what you get. Classy decor and great views overlooking Borough Market if you can get a table near the windows.

ZjCGGS-3r2RLSOAhnsXvEg.text: Update re Roast to Go. The pork belly sandwich is SO GOOD. They could maybe slightly improve the bread but basically it's a whole load of meat and fat for £6 and it tastes delicious.

Ii1Pi3nZ6bk4aRs5tqi-GQ.text: I happened to have been lucky enough while visiting London to have been randomly strolling through Borough Market on a cold Saturday, and looked up --- I saw what looked like a wonderful restaurant where we could sit and get warm over a few glasses of wine and some modern English cuisine.So, we asked some security personnel and market employees for directions on how to get upstairs and then made our way up in the elevator into a beautiful space with unfortunately, a very rude hostess.  The Roast hostess was clearly dismayed that we would dare enter such an establishment without a reservation and didn't even offer the suggestion to wait at the bar or to sit in the open seating in the lounge area.  She said, "You can try coming back in 45 minutes."  She then answered the phone and we weren't able to get her attention again to ask if what we suspected was lounge seating was in fact open.  It turns out that it was - thanks to the assistance from another server we sat down.From then on the experience was wonderful.  Servers worked collectively and the Sommelier appeared promptly upon request and made several recommendations on wine and encouraged and offered us tasting prior to choosing.The food ranged from pickled herring and beets, to grouse, and lambs livers.  Since I'm American and wanted to try something "British" that I'd never had before I went with the herring and partridge.  The meat was a tad overdone but the saucier at Roast knows his/her stuff.  My BF had the lambs livers and his sauce was possibly the most exquisite sauce I've ever had.  It was layered in flavor and rich beyond belief.  My sauce was also perfectly balanced and enhanced both the partridge and the brussel sprouts served with the dish.Roast had a broad menu but I'd venture a guess that their true focus is in meat and game so if you're a veggie you should probably not bother and just get some curry downstairs.  This place is for serious diners and foodies.I'd recommend this restaurant to any locals who are into nouveau British cuisine, or out of town guests who would appreciate the experience like we did.  It was a wonderful way to spend an afternoon.

photos.caption: Photo of Roast - London, United Kingdom. View from bar at Roast
Photo of Roast - London, United Kingdom. Borough Market
Photo of Roast - London, United Kingdom. Partridge and Lamb Livers

PX_oHREIHA45PBcS0mdoRQ.text: 2 words -  tourist trap.  When I was here with a friends, all we could do while eating was commiserate how we should have eaten at a food stall downstairs at the Borough Market instead.

bq54yV7T4-Xa3-KAJvZ_RA.text: Best cooked breakfast ever - go for a treat before/after visiting the market. My boyfriend particularly enjoyed the (huge) Bloody Mary. Fantastic service - not remotely stuffy.

sIJiHI_gcqHPmRCx4Cz7EQ.text: Sitting above the Borough food market eating here tastes and feels very fresh. Expect delicate starters and healthy portions of meat. The roast menu includes very good fish, meat and bird - when the description warns of possible buck shot you can't help to think the pheasant is fresh! The menu reads like grandma's country estate but presentation is west side.All items come with sauce and sides so don't look here for plain dishes. With a sensitive palette you may be bothered by all the salt. However, we ate here after a week long holiday in Paris and welcomed simple meats prepared in a more comfortable style.Restaurant is also comfortable albeit with white table clothes, pressed linen and a sharp staff. Eat by the open kitchen and watch your food take shape, by the windows peering over a bustling market, or on the raised platform to be center of attention.

photos.caption: Photo of Roast - London, United Kingdom
Photo of Roast - London, United Kingdom

65VH0eitG6x-pD6S_NOvGA.text: End of story: Beautiful location and interior. Breakfast is overpriced. and food was average.Our friend who lives in London was kind enough to take us to Roast for breakfast and show us around Borough Market.  While the ambiance is quite lovely, I almost wished we got food from the different vendors in the market below, which was cheaper and more interesting. The breakfast food was average, although I'm not sure this is because I'm American with an American palate.  I did love the bubble and squeak, but otherwise, the food was forgettable.

Plzr_o_-MCzcPIiLSK1_KA.text: Went to this place on a Sunday afternoon after seeing on a TV show where it was rated best roast dinner. It's set bang in the middle of borough market at London Bridge and is amazingly posh inside. I had what I had seen on the T.V show which was a rib eye beef roast dinner with all the trimmings. It's £75.....but it serves 2 people so only about £35. It's worth it for a one off special occasion. Great views of London's shard. The food was really nice but if I'm being totally honest I thought it was going to be a little bit better I can't really explain why. Over all a really nice one off treat.

iK97QutLN55iBiwNMLTfbw.text: Enjoyed a lovely dinner here.  I fell in love with Monkfish after having it here.  Cute location.  It is a more formal place so if you're not into formal style dining, then I would avoid.  Otherwise dine and enjoy!

bwc2lXMXlBA2Dt3n1d-8Tg.text: Great food in a great locationWent on a Saturday night and had the signature Beef Wellington which was great..very tender and sells out!  Good wine list...we had mostly English winesOnly problem .... ate so much that I had no space for desert!

CqOL79R9-JMBHr-TmxBmdQ.text: Best place for cocktails done the way they wee intended and amazing English food! One of my top places to eat on the planet!

c0VnLYoOD2jB0VW4to1agA.text: Roast is a hidden gem hanging above Borough Market and completely out of place with rough good natured hustle and bustle of the market itself. Not that that is necessarily a bad thing as it's a great respite from it all.As far as decor and food, I've give Roast 4 stars. The glazing on the windows completely blocks out the sounds of the market although the noise of the chatter inside is heavy enough to drown out a soft spoken work. The high windows and ceilings give it a very airy feel and on a sunny day it's almost like sitting outside.The food. I started off with sauteed scallops which were cooked perfectly, enough to lose the chill of a rare scallop but not too much where they become chewy. The fresh chives didn't add much to the flavour but the dry savoury nut (can't remember which nut it was) mousse added a great contrast to the inherent sweetness of the scallop.My main of pork belly with mashed potatoes and applesauce was overall quite good. Excellent mash without too much butter and the tart applesauce provided a good contrast to the sweet glaze used on the pork. The crackling was also excellently made. The meat itself was a bit of a let down, tender yes, but not as much flavour as I would expect from such a dish.Dessert was an acceptable chocolate tart but nothing to really write about.The things that knocked it down to 3 stars for me were i) the rude service, ii) the noise (hard to hold a conversation) and iii) poor table position (in the middle and away from the gorgeous views). Also, there was no one at the coat check when we left and we ended up making it self-service.Return Factor (credit to P. A. from Vegas for this concept): 70% especially as I have to try a namesake roast one Sunday

H6hc-EiwP1Hz4ffdCvAuQg.text: Yes the wine list is over priced as my friend Emma points out... but I cant get away from the space over the market.  I discovered it on my first trip to London years ago and typically hit it when I am back for a dinner.  So this trip I had surprised my partner with a ticket to join me in London as his Valentines' day surprise and wanted him to see this spot for dinner (as he has heard me talk about it a lot).  We had a reservation for 7 and were seated a few minutes early.  We shared the bone in filet for 2 and the beef was perfectly cooked and seasoned well.  The bottle of wine though pricy was lovely and the sticky date pudding for desert made for a special date night.

XhRF3_r3Cmp5xhZQ0AUbvQ.text: In short?Great food, great view, and good service. Actually, the ONLY restaurant I went to in London where the server seemed to care at all about me enjoying my experience. We sat at a table against the window, getting a great view of the Borough Market. I ate my first and only traditional English breakfast, and have a feeling that this was a much fancier, and less heavy version than is commonly served. The food came quickly, and the bartender actually took notice of when we had finished, and we were able to pay very shortly after eating, which is much more than I can say about everywhere else we dined in London. I would totally recommend Roast, and eat there again on my next trip to London.

zN681XkNQiE9lbMQncCnJw.text: Not cheap but not extortionate. Very tasty and filling. Posh breakfast is what I'd call it, the only downside was a slightly overcooked poached egg!!

photos.caption: Photo of Roast - London, United Kingdom

P44kgLogS359owtcaLqlNw.text: I took my boyfriend to Roast as a surprise to celebrate the end of the week. The restaurant itself nests above Borough market and as we entered there was a lady at a piano singing contemporary music jazz style. All very pleasing. The atmosphere was lively. When we got to order we naturally went for a roast (I think everything on the menu was a roasted something or the other). The price of a main (£30 to £40) is a little steep regardless of the fact that the cow had been reared on golden syrup. However, when the food came it was delicious. It's like having a really posh Sunday roast dinner in the evening. Beef was cooked to perfection. The wine list is extensive (and expensive) but worth going for something good. All in all a great evening. I would highly recommend.

3i7mKiXQdypgPdayyzp0TQ.text: The space is really nice, but I was underwhelmed by the food. I had a steak and chips, a watercress and green garlic soup, and the banaoffee pudding with devonshire cream.The only thing that truly wowed me was the dessert. And it was DELISH.For these prices, I enjoyed Jamie Oliver's Fifteen much better. Probably wouldn't go back.

llJS0Iu0fQZs1K761xqBjA.text: I think we managed to massively confuse the staff at Roast yesterday, and to give them their dues, they didn't flinch a bit when five sweaty and messy girls turned up for drinks. See, we'd just done a 5k run for charity and because I chose the run in the City, everywhere was shut when we finished which meant no drinks for us. I always forget what a wasteland that area turns into on a Sunday. Which meant the only place open nearby (it was only just 12). Roast was it. We only wanted drinks, and they perched us at the bar with our soggy running stuff and little medals. Then we drank our way through the cocktail menu. Every single cocktail I tried was excellent. The star of the afternoon was a strawberry bellini thing which had a heck of a lot of vodka in it. Their cocktails are inventive and the bar staff a really friendly. The downside? It's VERY expensive. Cocktails are around the £10-11 mark, and I know it's fancy, but my friend got 15p change after buying a beer and a COKE. There needs to be something very special about a beer that costs six quid, (and the staff need to learn how to pour something that's been bottle conditioned). But, then I remember how yummy the cocktails were, and how friendly they were given that we looked a bedraggled mess, so it's four stars from me even though we didn't have anything to eat. I can't afford to come here often, and I think the bar feels more like a waiting area for the restaurant, but a very fun time was had by all.

HZh_5JtR-0YoRWT77IibGg.text: We walked here from Tate Modern and entered this Borough Market warehouse like structure. Entering the dining room you feel like you're on a film set. It's industrial and open. The main dining floor is raised overlooking the kitchen area and sat there you see all the hustle and bustle.I didn't get pics of my slow-roasted free-range pork belly with mashed potatoes and Bramley apple sauce, but it was just how modern British homemade food should be. Nicely cooked meat, lashings of gravy and potatoes you want more of. It was washed down with some nice wine. I'm can't remember if there was time or room in the belly for dessert. I do know that we walked along the banks of the River Thames back to our hotel. A perfect night.There are daily specials: chicken, liver, lamb, ham, beef...and the Sunday 3-course meal! All look amazing on the website roast-restaurant.com/roa…

W04myLJJXwG3RE9IuE3ogg.text: Desserts came not only with recommended dessert wines, but with recommended cocktails. I'm not very good at daytime drinking, but you can guess how I feel about matched cocktails....Full review on Blackheath.london

photos.caption: Photo of Roast - London, United Kingdom. Chicken at Roast!  Full Review on Blackheath.London

Whzu2bp5BlooWDvsy6sTog.text: This spot in Borough Market is fancy and has really snobby hostesses which is never a nice thing. They forgot one of our appetizers, and didn't understand a modification request (we went for brunch and I asked for fried eggs instead of poached). But my salmon and egg poach was good otherwise. I also ordered dropped scones not realizing that those aren't scones at all, but more like pancakes (fail!) which were served with stewed fruit (I am not a fan of these - I prefer fresh). The decor feels corporate but there are nice big windows and views of the market and surrounds.

OJOB4lrRI0YaL02UkUpoOg.text: Very nice food and drinks, great atmosphere, live music, good location, friendly staff . I would recommend and will definitely be back in the near future . Love it !

yb-jCclHd2URCyIbOB2G4A.text: We hadnt planned on coming here but after arriving at Borough Market and remembering that we didnt have any cash and was starving, we walked to find a restaurant that would take credit cards. I am sure glad we came here! We came here during lunch without a reservation and was seated right away. Husband ordered the fish and chips and I got the sea cod. The cod was the BEST I have ever tasted. The skin was perfectly crisped and the whole dish was well seasoned with the mashed potatoes and sea greens. Best meal I had while I was in London.

lxleHBSVGcugL7xgbFSkkQ.text: The food was really good, just as was the wine. The ambience was cool, but a bit too loud. Overall a good experience, but I would not consider it eye opening.

jyU6F9CnLaVSZxCQCEFyEg.text: Went there on St Pat's day.  Mixed review.  Pros - food was good, my halibut was really good and really nice atmosphere.  Cons - pricey,  nose in the air service and the Yorkshire pudding wasn't traditional.  If you go, the entrance is in the middle of the market; otherwise you might walk around the building a few times.  No saying I did that, just saying.....

bTXgYmoasqR4DecawIB84A.text: I saw Andrew Zimmern go to ROAST on an episode of "Bizarre Food" once and made a mental note to go there the next time I was in London. I love British food, which is probably odd for a Thai person, but mark it up to nostalgia for my youth spent mostly in England. The opportunity came in August 2010 when I had to go to the UK for a friend's wedding. Booked a table ahead of time. I loved the concept of the changing menus and seasonal ingredients etc. It was definitely a high end restaurant and the people on the tables near us looked like they could have been some politicians or VIPs. We got a very nice table by the big windows that over looked a couple of pubs below so we got to do a lot of people watching as many of them were standing drinking outside on the streets .... it was warm in August and they were probably the smokers.The menu choice du jour was all mouth watering but we all had to make a decision in the end. (see photos) I loved everything that I got. The only complaint probably was how expensive it all was; even though I didn't pay for the meal myself! And a little bit on the pretentious / snooty side.  I do love gourmet and haute cuisine from time to time but if I have to break the bank to have it then I can certainly live without it. I think it is certainly possible to make very fine food at a reasonable price.Final verdict: Although I was very happy with the meal overall, I thought it was overpriced and a bit pretentious. It was great to get to try it once but I probably won't bother going back. Unless someone with very deep pockets wants to take me .... anyone? Just kidding.

photos.caption: Photo of Roast - London, United Kingdom. the desserts we ordered
Photo of Roast - London, United Kingdom. Slow cooked salted duck leg
Photo of Roast - London, United Kingdom. Slow roast Wicks Manor Pork belly

Dv_WXIrz7Mg7MM1XTiVe_Q.text: Pretty good full bodied English and Scottish breakfast. Everything is fried and grilled so it is difficult to judge based on just breakfast. We didn't really like the english pudding and felt it was really salty. Overall however it is helped by a nice location overlooking Borough market where one can take time over breakfast and just people watch.

photos.caption: Photo of Roast - London, United Kingdom. Breakfast overlooking the surroundings of Borough market

LB4jzN4PyjC9NH-tH116-w.text: I usually go here for Breakfast. They have the 'Early Bird' special before 08:00, so get yo' ass down there for some great food. My friend usually has the porridge, which she says is really good. I, on the other hand, prefer something a bit more substantial for breakfast and alternate between the full english (Full Borough I think they call it) and the 'to-die-for' caramelised bananas with french bread and bacon. Simply perfect.The dinner and lunch services are very good too, quintessential British food at its finest. Their steaks are really good, and they cook all the food very well. The waiting staff are very polite and helpful, happy to accommodate any needs. What I would say is that if you have a vegetarian with you, this might not be the best place to go as it is very meat-orientated.N.B.: When calling to make a reservation, ask for a window seat. That way you can enjoy your meal looking out across St Paul's Cathedral and the amazing views of London.

XAzx6DsqUHchdW7NiXj75g.text: Great location. Great atmosphere. Really tasty food but slightly on the expensive side.Service adequate.

-8mDlyfwffHWa21ACxfS9w.text: We used to come often but for some reasons had not been for 12 months. What a disappointment today. The room is still spectacular with great views over the market and St Paul, especially on a bright, sunny day like today. The service is still very professional, if somewhat codified. However the food was simply poor. Our starter called a lamb salad turned out to be deep fried lamb with a few salad leaves. The dish was very greasy and the lamb was more fat than meat with little taste. The main course used to be a great dish due to the quality of the beef. This time the burger was so salty you could not taste anything. I hope for Roast this was a one off. If not, avoid at all cost.

photos.caption: Photo of Roast - London, United Kingdom

6hUOaYsdh9ys3E00GmBihQ.text: Good food for the price, but poor poor service.  Shortly after we finished our meal (starter, main course, and dessert), the waitress came over and asked us to free up our table while half of the restaurant was empty.  (We didn't go cheap either, our bill was around 230£ for 3 people.)

photos.caption: Photo of Roast - London, United Kingdom. 28 days aged porterhouse

0FSJKlx8hJ2g5xO3fVui5Q.text: Great food, nice location, good staff, quite an extensive wine list.The Scotch Eggs were the best I've ever had, and the roast pork was excellent: the roast beef looked great, I'll have to have that next time.Perhaps a little expensive, but for the quality that you get highly recommended!

photos.caption: Photo of Roast - London, United Kingdom

_sYqF2m2zdDQZfz8oY8WjA.text: Made a reservation well in advance of the trip to London for Roast and was completely impressed with the quality of the food and the attentiveness of the staff. Great location for the restaurant,  right above borough market. Loved the ambience inside though it was a bit loud as we were seated right next to the kitchen. All in all, each of the 3 courses were delicious. Very pricey but worth the money and the trip.

aeC7alYBa4UO0GIWHXKf4g.text: Great service. Great food. Great atmosphere with a view. It was a great way to get away from the cold and rainy London weather. Good beer selection also.

photos.caption: Photo of Roast - London, United Kingdom. Middle : Scotch Burford Brown egg . Top left: Bath Pig chorizo croquettes. Top right : pork belly. Bottom right : halibut

KnPy_SMuoz1Vt-A1Sz8PNw.text: EXCELLENT!!! We made a reservation for tonight for 6:30 , we walked in and we greeted by very sweet ladies who checked our coats as its a rainy mess in London tonight. The service was pretty good tip is included in the UK at restraraunts so I guess no need to really hustle but they were still good just a tad slow. We started with the celery and blue soup, not sure what to expect but OMG it was fantastic hot warm creamy soup with walnuts and blue cheese gosh it was perfect . Then my husband and I  (honeymoon) had the chateaubriand for two with a side of glazed carrots and added two sauces on the side bone marrow and bernaise. The meat was cooked medium to perfection  ( this dish is a timed dish 40 mins wait) it was worth the wait.  The little roasted potatoes were wonderful the sauces were on point but best of all it came with the best Yorkshire pudding I've ever had fill the hole of it with the most delicious gravy from the pan dripping we ordered more of the gravy too yum, the carrots were awesome as well. If in London stop by it is FAB

MPf0Q-Eq_NtDQXqRSAplfg.text: Delicious full English and Eggs Florentine on a Sunday although it was nothing special. I'd like to come back to try the lunches or dinners but it's a bit expensive for what it is. The staff weren't very attentive which was a little disappointing.

b4c5B2--_LZjbIdTOjh_wg.text: Atmosphere was incredible - right above Borough Market.  We we there for brunch and the food was good, the streaky bacon was delicious and the bubble and squeak was excellent.  We took our kids 4 and 8 and while it was really nice it was very kid friendly. I would definitely go back to try it out for dinner.

L2gK4cICH4p6dA8aycDTvA.text: Roast Restaurant overlooking Borough Market is an outstanding example of British food. Its focus, as the name suggest is the favorite (Sunday) roast, accompanied by fresh seasonal produce acquired from the market below. Its signature dish, a Pork Belly roast is a treat for the senses with its crispy crackling encompassing the melt in your mouth tenderness of the meat. Accompanied by Brambly apple sauce and fluffy mashed potatoes, it is a perfectly balanced dish. Puddings are decidedly English, the wine list is international and all of it makes for a superb dining experience.

oG_bK_PyBcpVHom4_LyrQg.text: It's well situated, but service is lacking and the food is about average for its class while the price is above average.Food: had the braised pork belly with whipped potatoes. The belly was unctuous and slightly herbaceous with a crunchy, chewy skin. The fish & chips were pretty standard.Service: we didn't have reservations for lunch so we waited at the bar while tables started opening up around us. When we saw they weren't being filled, and the hostess hadn't notified us that a table was available, we asked again and were seated a few minutes later and given menus. The menus were blank. So we asked for menus with actual menus which were quickly provided. Thereafter service was fine, nothing memorable or outstanding. Overall, the food and service value didn't match the price tag.

photos.caption: Photo of Roast - London, United Kingdom. Braised pork belly, applesauce and whipped potatoes.

G49HhzZrYYjBdQGAvJ8T6g.text: My parents and I wanted a cup of coffee and a place to sit in the hustle and bustle of Borough Market, and we mistakenly took Roast for a cafe. Luckily there was a table available even though the place was packed. We really just wanted coffee so we ordered a French press, but we felt too guilty to take up a table in this fancy place without having any food. My parents shared the fish and chips, which was probably the most expensive fish and chips that I've ever laid eyes on. Unfortunately the fish was a bit bland and could have used a bit more salt. But not dry at all and great batter. My charcuterie plate was lovely, absolutely no complaints. I also got the Orange Bombshell which consists of "Roast gin, Mandarin Napoleon liqueur, Kamm and Son's ginseng liqueur, Grand Marnier, lemon curd, and orange juice shaken and served on a frozen orange." It was a delicious drink, but the presentation seemed a little.. juvenile? The description does mention that it comes in a frozen orange, but a small plate or shallow cup would have been nice as the orange kept staining the table.As others have mentioned, it's expensive but the service was great and you get a nice view over the market.

D10Eb69QtqpHTe4VN6dvfg.text: The roast is awesome and the sticky toffee pudding too! I'd definitely go back there again for any of those! I wish the service was a bit better organized and calm! The waitress serving me was going around like a rocket and didn't even give me time to say thank you or please because she didn't really have the time to wait after I ordered for example! Still, the food is awesome! A bit over priced but I would say it's worth it once or twice...

photos.caption: Photo of Roast - London, United Kingdom. Sticky toffee pudding
Photo of Roast - London, United Kingdom. Sunday roast

RKoasw5ppT_kiXEwp8loOg.text: A wonderful dining experience close to Borough Market and The Shard, both of which we had just visited. The roast beef was, of course, memorable and the sides delicious. The grilled octopus and calamari appetizer was as well-prepared as a fine seafood restaurant. And deserts and the extensive list of dessert wines completed an outstanding dining experience.The sommelier was extremely helpful, matching our courses with a wonderful and not over-priced Bordeaux Red. We will go back when next in London.

cWENm_fhOW-DXstevFtFyg.text: This is a nice restaurant. It sits above Borough Market, which couldn't be more picturesque. The service was great, the restaurant is beautiful and we enjoyed our meal. Would recommend it!

Hdz-Yk1OK1Hzslpu7wDIxw.text: I can't remember the last time I had a good Sunday roast. Sundays for me now consist of curries or Thai or hungover Dominos but you can't beat a nice big roast with all the trimmings.I was recently given a voucher so I could go & enjoy dinner at Roast in Borough Market. They very kindly agreed to let me swap my dinner reservation for a Sunday lunch time booking so I could make the most of their three courses for £37.50 deal. Roast serves great British food from their glass-windowed restaurant located in the middle of Borough Market. It's owned by Iqbal Wahhab, the founder of Cinnamon Club and it's a famed for its use of seasonal produce. We decided to kick our meal off with some fancy looking cocktails. Tom went for the Mango Tarragon Martini (£12) made with Roast gin infused with fresh tarragon, fresh mango puree and elderflower cordial. Lovely and fruity and very strong. I went for the SE1 spICED tea (£12) an even stronger blend of gin, bourbon, citrus infused vodka, rum, cointreau and sugar, topped with ginger ale. Despite containing half the contents of the bar, it's surprisingly refreshing and the perfect way to start out off meal. I started off our three courses with the pork and black pudding scotch egg served with piccalilli which was incredible. The egg was perfectly cooked so the yolk was still runny and ran into the crisp meaty casing. I felt the piccalilli was a little over-powering so I recommend using it sparingly.  Tom went for the pressed wild rabbit and ham hock terrine which came with fig chutney and toasted sour-dough. Not quite to my taste but Tom really enjoyed it. The main courses were where Roast really lived up to its name. The roast pork belly came with the biggest piece of crackling I've ever seen. The meat was perfectly cooked and had that rich, melt-in-the-mouth quality - not too fatty but still packed with flavour.   Lamb is Tom's favourite so he went for the rosemary and garlic studded leg of lamb with redcurrant jelly and mint sauce. Perfectly tender and served with an extra-large yorkshire pudding. Roast really know how to spoil you with the extras!All the roasts come with a selection of beef dripping roasties, seasonal green veg and carrots. If you're anything like me - order an extra round of gravy which the staff are more than happy to bring out.After all that food we had to activate our second 'dessert stomachs' so we could squeeze in room for pudding. Tom went for a piping hot Bramley apple crumble served with the creamiest vanilla custard while I predictably went for the sticky date pudding with toffee sauce and clotted cream. (They can call it sticky date pudding all they want, it will always be Sticky Toffee)The three-course Sunday lunch is brilliant value but the alcohol doesn't come cheap. The cheapest bottle of wine is around £40 and they increase steadily from there so the bill can rack up pretty quickly!Roast would make a really lovely spot if you're heading out for a celebration. It'a a little pricey so while it's probably not somewhere I would come every weekend, I would definitely recommend it for a birthday or an occasional treat.

7LDdpDo6FTOru70JC13TBw.text: what was ordered:-pork belly (good enough for two ppl)-special-wine60 gbplocated inside the Borough Market.  Take the elevator up or the stairs.  Can't miss it.  Looks a like a greenhouse.

fosZWsxiG-165oYsB9gAHw.text: Another superb breakfast at Roast. Went in on St Patrick's Day and had an 'Irish' breakfast, which was jolly nice. Sausage, scrambled eggs, black pudding, tomatoes, bacon, mushrooms. My only criticism is that the juice I ordered (mango), wasn't particularly nice and was very expensive at £7!

GjlrLNpmOiyB9-NlPnOK-g.text: I would have rather eaten the delicious options downstairs from the market vendors, but my wife wanted to have more of a meal so we went to Roast. Presentation was good, service ok/good and food was good, but again nothing special. I had the scotch egg, nice pork belly and my wife had the Hake which was accompanied by a rather too citrusy salad. The date pudding(sticky toffee pudding) was absolutely delicious and surprisingly light!!Not crazy expensive, but I still wish I had eaten in the market instead!

RAZJtnMHZekQdAfmaRgAPQ.text: One of my favorite places to visit when I'm in London. Situated above Borough Market, it's a true farm-to-table experience, with many vendors from the market supplying meat and produce.Reservations are needed for the better tables with a view, but you can on occasion walk in and snag a table. On a recent visit we had the lobster with tandoori spices and hamburger. Both were to die for!My only regret is I didn't pick up a cookbook, and they aren't released on Amazon until September.

OSpYiFbZanJJ_286xjeH4Q.text: I had a very nice lunch at Roast.  I had the Roast Ripley Castle redleg partridgewith creamed Brussels sprouts, wild boar bacon and chestnuts.  This was very tasty.  The sauce was delicious and went well with the partridge.  We ordered some sides too (purple sprouting broccoli which actually wasn't purple and spinach).  The slight downfall the meal is the indifferent service.  It's nothing awful but no one came to refill our water glasses or asked if we wanted more wine.  Great views of Borough Market though and definitely worth bringing friends visiting from out of town.  Try and get a seat near the window.  We sat in the bar and it was quite spacious, given all the other complaints about crowded dining areas in previous posts.

egTZDW-yxW1k5oIfMXLeog.text: Beautiful restaurant situated right above Borough market. My sister made the reservation and made sure we got there at the exact time. We got seated towards the back since we had a toddler. At least we were close to the kitchen where we could check them out. I know a few of us ordered fish and chips and I can't even remember what I ordered. Might've been some sort of poultry. I have to give them a thumbs up for their service. There was a waitress that totally took a liking to my toddler and really made him feel special. There was also a musician that night and the kid was swaying to the music. The ladies at the front also gave him a balloon while we were leaving. While the food might not have been so memorable, their service definitely stood out.

2uz9ZurLULv1B3eM9UzacQ.text: We made reservations a day or two in advance and came here for lunch on a weekday. Got seated immediately and we were served bread and butter. After perusing the menu, we ordered pork belly, chicken and mushrooms.The pork belly comes with apple sauce and I normally don't like anything sweet with meat. So they accommodated my request to bring the apple sauce on the side. The chicken and mushrooms dishes were good. Pork belly comes with a side of mashed potatoes and was really delicious!The portion size was big, so couldn't finish the entire dish. Didn't even have space for dessert.Highly recommend this place.

otxrDuuZeEFqY3IWUGGE-Q.text: Sitting by the window with a view of bustling Borough Market is a lovely way to start your weekend. The coffee was great and my breakfast was delicious. I had serious food envy looking around me. Will most definately come again - when you book ask for a table overlooking the market by the glass pane, otherwise there is a risk they will seat you lower.

9UEWVJKthRqoV7RzjLuYnA.text: It's above borough market and it was a great experience. The staff was accommodating towards us and continued refilling our water. The food was brought out in a timely manner. The food was expensive but it was worth it. The meal was filling and tasted great . It's definitely worth going to.

moLdZ54BOT1HZBtHcBIVbA.text: Worst breakfast in London I've had. The atmosphere and the place itself is okay (hence the two stars), but the food was so oily (I had the kedgeree) I couldn't eat much of it and felt ill afterwards.

AAG0LM7-3MoZXDTlBpO97g.text: When ever we go borough market we always get a pork sandwich from the Roast hut so nice melts in mouth, tasty and the crackling sot juicy and crunchy.  Also have eaten in main restaurant as well and again food very tasty, you get a big portions for your money and the staff are very friendly highly recommend

5o0asy7-Hq9z9Jr62X3NAw.text: Coyly situated upstairs in the Borough Market area, this place is really where you want to go for modern British cuisine and excellent service. High ceilings and flooding light from the surrounding window panes makes for a gorgeous space. Very simple, white, spacious with a fantastic bar (an important criteria).We came in here on a Saturday around 7:30pm and I was surprised at how unpretentious they were about seating, considering that Roast is quite up-scale and popular. Was impressed that it was good old clean classy. The staff was extremely polite and attentive. The sommelier's patience was impressive as we asked him for a recommendation all having ordered very different mains. He was very professional and knowledgeable as were the other staff members, recommending appetizers to complement our entrees. Being cursed/blessed with a reasonably sized sweet-tooth, I opted for entree and dessert rather than appetizer and entree. The menu was problematic in the best way. Everything sounded fantastic and well thought-out. After a good 10 minutes of back and forth I settled on the roast rump of Launceston lamb with crispy potato and ramson cake. I thought the potato was fine but could have had a little more flavor or crunch but the pea shoots complemented it nicely, though there was just not enough of it for me The portions were a bit inconsistent in terms of size as the people around me had huge mounds of mash with their pork belly while the person across from me had meagre amount of side. However, the lamb was delectable, well cooked and tender, and served with an acidic salsa which cut through the dish expertly. And the dessert. Requires a separate paragraph. Amazing. The goats cheese cheesecake was just the most fantastic thing. Not being a fan of anything too sweet or heavy, this was perfect for me. The usually hardened crust was transformed into almost a coating on a subtly sweet creamy delight of cheesecake goodness. Accompanying it was a lovely poached strawberry sauce, allowing you to add your desired amount of sweetness. Perfection.The negatives are few. One, it took a while to get our bill and we were given the wrong menus a couple of times. Also, if you are faced the open oven/kitchen area rather than the other side, then it isn't a very pretty dining experience. It was loud in general volume and the portion sizes were off as I would not have been full had it not been for us ordering extra sides to an already pricey bill. The wines are expensive, though understandably so.Most certainly on my list of best retaurants. I will be back to try the tempting Wellington and the Roast Goosnargh duck with star anise infused whipped cauliflower and sour cherry sauce!

IhcK0z275tVFCH_olpPjTw.text: Hype and chic - good English food nice set up. One amongst many places to go to in London give it a try and you will come back.

PL5ksTsB3-f195_d3Q_B6w.text: The restaurant is nice and airy.  Live music when we were there but a bit loud.  The food and service was average and really nothing to write or complain about.  But this place really is not that cheap.  For an extra 10 GBP, you can get a much nicer roast at The Grill at The Dorchester for its Sunday Roast in the amazing dining room.  Not a terrible place if you are in the neighborhood and want roast.  But at this price point, I almost feel like it should be a special occasion and we probably won't be coming back here if we are in the mood for the roast.

lQohXqRejHVB_oXUx9rUqA.text: Roast is conveniently located above borough market with a fab view of the market! The food is delicious. They do a three course menu at lunch for 30£ (started, main course and dessert). I ordered the watermelon, mozzarella and tomato salad as the starter. It was good - refreshing and light. I went for the fish as the main course, which was delicately cooked and not over cooked! Hooray. Over cooked fish is the worst! Lastly, for dessert, I ordered the apple and raspberry crumble with vanilla custard. So yum! For an additional 5£, you can add a glass of prosecco. We did and it was worth it. Roast is also surprisingly kid friendly. They have change tables in the bathroom (women's only ) and high chairs. Kids eat free in school holidays!

1H-AASqQvJL9l8tunkqaQA.text: To be honest food wasn't that bad. Was acceptable in terms of quality. The roast I had in fact was quite good, despite the limited dinner menu on a Sunday night and then fact that lot of items were sold out.The sirloin roast I had was cook medium rare, just right for me and the cut was nice.The entire however was only alright with the poached salmon, slightly on he bland side and the veg didn't mix as well as I'd like.Dessert I had the white chocolate pudding and it was really good. The only thing that was odd was the peach source that didn't go very well.All in all the food there were lots to like, however everything was just 1 star shy of perfection. Overall deserves a solid 4 star.Now, why did I put a 3 star down if they deserve a solid 4 star then? It comes down to the fact that, they forced us to have last order at 6:30pm, when our booking was at 6:15pm. The rush was unnecessary and I personally think if that was the case it should have been clearly communicated st the booking!

photos.caption: Photo of Roast - London, United Kingdom
Photo of Roast - London, United Kingdom

qLSJSGD5poV6TXW5l64ERA.text: Went for their special summer menu for 30£ or 32 with a glass of prosecco and was pleasantly surprised.Starters: we all went for the scotch egg which was good but the piccalli was very sour for meMains: we went for the roast lamb, pea tortellini and the pork belly and all were delicious!!! Desserts: peanut butter and chocolate mousse (very good and Im not a chocolate person) and the crumble (good but nothing special)Overall a great experience and I would go back and try Sunday roast!
